docTitle.titlePart:
Mr VVILLIAM
SHAKESPEARES
COMEDIES,
HISTORIES, &
TRAGEDIES.
Publiſhed according to the True Originall Copies.

titlePage.docImprint: London : Printed by Isaac Iaggard, and Ed. Blount [at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley]., 1623.

foliation.p: Numbering peculiarities: 1st count: p.50 misnumbered 58; p.59 misnumbered 51; p.86 misnumbered 88; p.153 misnumbered 151; p.161 misnumbered] 163; p.164 misnumbered 162; p. 165 misnumbered 163; p. 189 misnumbered 187; p. 249 misnumbered 251; p.250 misnumbered 252; p. 265 misnumbered 273 -- 2nd count: p.37 misnumbered 39 in some copies; p.89 misnumbered 91; p. 90 misnumbered 92 -- 3rd count: p.165-166 numbered 167 and 168 respectively; p. 216 numbered 218 -- 5th count: p. 279 misnumbered 259; p. 282 misnumbered 280; p.308 misnumbered 38; p. 379 misnumbered 389; p. 399 misnumbered 993.

collation.p: The signatures varies between sources, with the most commonly cited being Hinman's and West's: 1. Hinman: πA⁶ (πA1+1) [πB²], ²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ χgg⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ χ1.2 [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ aa-ff⁶ gg² Gg⁶ hh⁶ kk-bbb⁶; 2. West: πA⁶ (πA1+1, πA5+1.2)²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ ²g⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ 'gg3.4' (±'gg3') [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ 2a-2f⁶ 2g² 2G⁶ 2h⁶ 2k-2v⁶ x⁶ 2y-3b⁶.
Mis-signed leaves: a3 mis-signed Aa3; ³gg1 mis-signed Gg; nn1-nn2 mis-signed Nn and Nn2 and oo1 mis-signed Oo.
"The life and death of King Iohn" begins new pagination on leaf a1 recto; "The tragedy of Coriolanus" begins new pagination on leaf aa1 recto.

supportDesc.condition: Lacks A1, the letterpress frontispiece entitled "To the reader". The title page is trimmed and mounted, with a section of the mount towards the foot of the leaf mutilated resulting in the loss of some the Droechout imprint at the bottom left hand corner of the portrait and the central section of an early MS note. For a full condition report, including a full survey of damage and repairs, please contact Rare Books.

layout.p: Colophon reads: "Printed at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley. 1623.".
Editors’ dedication signed: Iohn Heminge. Henry Condell.

decoDesc.decoNote: With an engraved title-page portrait of the author signed: "Martin- Droeshout: sculpsit· London.". The plate exists in 2 states: 1. The earlier state has lighter shading generall ; 2. Later state has heavier shading, especially around the collar, and minor differences particularly with the jawline and moustache. The vast majority of surviving copies have the plate in the second state which has led some scholars to conclude that the earlier state was a proof. The portrait in this copy is the second state.

additions.p: Two MS verses on first endpaper verso: 1. 9 lines of verse by an unknown author, first line reads "An active swain to make a leap was seen". 2. A copy of Ben Jonson’s printed "To the Reader"; MS note on t.p. (mutilated) appears to read "Honest [Shakes]peare". Minor annotations on leaf 2n4 (Macbeth). All in an early English hand, presumably added after leaving the Library.

bindingDesc.p: Seventeenth-century (1624) English (Oxford) smooth calf. Bound for the Bodleian Library by William Wildgoose, with evidence of two cloth ties, red sprinkled edge. Formerly chained, with evidence of chain staple at the head of the upper cover. Remains of paper label at the head of the spine. Enclosed in 20th century book box by Maltby of Oxford. See S. Gibson in Original Bodleian Copy of First Folio, p. 12-13. One of four items sent out on 17th February 1624 for binding by Wildgoose containing printed waste from a copy of Cicero’s "De Officiis, et al." [Deventer: Richard Pafraet, between 1480 and 1485] as paste-downs. For more information on this work see: Bod. Inc. Cat., C-322.

origin.p: For further details on the printing of this item see Hinman, Charleton. The printing and proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare: Oxford, 1963.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bodleian in 1623, presumably in sheets. It was sent out to William Wildgoose on 17 February 1624 for binding (see: Library Records e.258, fol. 48r) and upon its return chained in Duke Humfrey at shelfmark S 2.17 Art. It is listed in the Bodleian’s 1635 catalogue of printed books but was gone by the publication of the next catalogue in 1674, replaced by the newer Third Folio (1664). There is no explicit reference in Library Records to the disposal of this copy, but there is a record of a sale of "superfluous library books" to Richard Davis, a bookseller in Oxford, in 1664 for the sum of £24.

After leaving the Bodleian this copy entered the collection of Richard Turbutt of Ogston Hall, Derbyshire at some point in the early 18th century. It stayed in the family’s possession until 1906, when it was reacquired by the Bodleian for the sum of £3000, raised by public subscription. For a full discussion of the rediscovery and purchase of this copy see: F. Madan, G. M. R. Turbutt and S. Gibson, The Original Bodleian Copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare (theTurbutt Shakespeare) (Oxford, 1905)
For a full discussion of this copy and the digital version see http://shakespeare.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/ and West and Rasmussen (2011), 31.

listBibl.bibl: Digital facsimile images available at: http://firstfolio.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/.

person.persName: Sir Hugh Evans, a Welsh parson
Ford, a gentleman dwelling at Windsor
Host, host of the Garter Inn
Page, a gentleman dwelling at Windsor
Hostess Quickly, hostess of a tavern in Eastcheap
William Page, a boy, son to Page

div.head: Actus primus, Scena prima.
[Act 1, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Iustice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Master
Page, Falstoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Pistoll, Anne Page,
Mistresse Ford, Mistresse Page, Simple.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p:
SIr Hugh, perswade me not: I will make a Star‑Chamber
matter of it, if hee were twenty Sir
Iohn Falstoffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow
Esquire.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
In the County of Glocester, Iustice of Peace and
(Coram.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I (Cosen Slender) and Cust‑alorum.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I, and Rato lorum too; and a Gentleman borne
(Master Parson) who writes himselfe Armigero, in any
Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I that I doe, and haue done any time these three
hundred yeeres.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
All his successors (gone before him) hath don't:
and all his Ancestors (that come after him) may: they
may giue the dozen white Luces in their Coate.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: It is an olde Coate.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
The dozen white Lowses doe become an old
Coat well: it agrees well passant: It is a familiar beast to
man, and signifies Loue.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
The Luse is the fresh‑fish, the salt‑fish, is an old
Coate.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I may quarter (Coz).

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.l: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Yes per‑lady: if he ha's a quarter of your coat,
there is but three Skirts for your selfe, in my simple con­
iectures; but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falstaffe haue
committed disparagements vnto you, I am of the Church
and will be glad to do my beneuolence, to make attone­
ments and compremises betweene you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Councell shall heare it, it is a Riot.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
It is not meet the Councell heare a Riot: there
is no feare of Got in a Riot: The Councell (looke you)
shall desire to heare the feare of Got, and not to heare a
Riot: take your viza‑ments in that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha; o' my life, if I were yong againe, the sword
should end it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
It is petter that friends is the sword, and end
it: and there is also another deuice in my praine, which
peraduenture prings goot discretions with it. There is
Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas Page,
which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Mistris Anne Page? she has browne haire, and
speakes small like a woman.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
It is that ferry person for all the orld, as iust as
you will desire, and seuen hundred pounds of Moneyes,
and Gold, and Siluer, is her Grand‑sire vpon his deaths‑
bed, (Got deliuer to a ioyfull resurrections) giue, when
she is able to ouertake seuenteene yeeres old. It were a
goot motion, if we leaue our pribbles and prabbles, and
desire a marriage betweene Master Abraham, and Mistris
Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Did her Grand‑sire leaue her seauen hundred
pound?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I, and her father is make her a petter penny.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I know the young Gentlewoman, she hasgood
gifts.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Seuen hundred pounds, and possibilities, is
goot gifts.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wel, let vs see honest Mr Page: is Falstaffe there?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you a lye? I doe despise a lyer, as I
doe despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not
true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beseech you be
ruled by your well‑willers: I will peat the doore for Mr.
Page. What hoa? Got‑plesse your house here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Here is go't's plessing and your friend, and Iu­
stice Shallow, and heere yong Master Slender: that perad­
uentures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to
your likings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p:
I am glad to see your Worships well: I
thanke you for my Venison Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good
doe it your good heart: I wish'd your Venison better, it
was ill killd: how doth good Mistresse Page? and I thank
you alwaies with my heart, la: with my heart.

sp.speaker: M.Page.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke you: by yea, and no I doe.

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
How do's your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard
say he was out‑run on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: It could not be iudg'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: You'll not confesse: you'll not confesse.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That he will not, 'tis your fault, 'tis your fault:
'tis a good dogge.

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: A Cur, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir: hee's a good dog, and a faire dog, can there
be more said? he is good, and faire. Is Sir Iohn Falstaffe
heere?

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.p:
Sir, hee is within: and I would I could doe a
good office betweene you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speake.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: He hath wrong'd me (Master Page.)

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: Sir, he doth in some sort confesse it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
If it be confessed, it is not redressed; is not that
so (M. Page?) he hath wrong'd me, indeed he hath, at a
word he hath: beleeue me, Robert Shallow Esquire, saith
he is wronged.

sp.speaker: Ma.Pa
sp.l: Here comes Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, Master Shallow, you'll complaine of me to
the King?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Knight, you haue beaten my men, kill'd my
deere, and broke open my Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: But not kiss'd your Keepers daughter?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Tut, a pin: this shall be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I will answere it strait, I haue done all this:
That is now answer'd.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: The Councell shall know this.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
'Twere better for you if it were known in coun­cell:
you'll be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good worts? good Cabidge; Slender, I broke
your head: what matter haue you against me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Marry sir, I haue matter in my head against you,
and against your cony‑catching Rascalls, Bardolf, Nym,
and Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You Banbery Cheese.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: How now, Mephostophilus?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Slice, I say; pauca, pauca: Slice, that's my humor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Where's Simple my man? can you tell, Cosen?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
Peace, I pray you: now let vs vnderstand: there
is three Vmpires in this matter, as I vnderstand; that is,
Master Page (fidelicet Master Page,) & there is my selfe,
(fidelicet my selfe) and the three party is (lastly, and fi­nally)
mine Host of the Gater.

sp.speaker: Ma.Pa
sp.l: We three to hear it, & end it between them.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Ferry goo't, I will make a priefe of it in my
note‑booke, and we wil afterwards orke vpon the cause,
with as great discreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: He heares with eares.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
The Teuill and his Tam: what phrase is this?
he heares with eare? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pistoll, did you picke M. Slenders purse?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I, by these gloues did hee, or I would I might
neuer come in mine owne great chamber againe else, of
seauen groates in mill‑sixpences, and two Edward Sho­uelboords,
that cost me two shilling and two pence a
peece of Yead Miller: by these gloues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Is this true, Pistoll?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: No, it is false, if it is a picke‑purse.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Ha, thou mountaine Forreyner: Sir Iohn, and
Master mine, I combat challenge of this Latine Bilboe:
word of deniall in thy labras here; word of denial; froth,
and scum thou liest.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: By these gloues, then 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
Be auis'd sir, and passe good humours: I will
say marry trap with you, if you runne the nut‑hooks hu­mor
on me, that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
By this hat, then he in the red face had it: for
though I cannot remember what I did when you made
me drunke, yet I am not altogether an asse.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What say you Scarlet, and Iohn?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Why sir, (for my part) I say the Gentleman had
drunke himselfe out of his fiue sentences.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It is his fiue sences: fie, what the ignorance is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
And being fap, sir, was (as they say) casheerd: and
so conclusions past the Car‑eires.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I, you spake in Latten then to: but 'tis no mat­ter;
Ile nere be drunk whilst I liue againe, but in honest,
ciuill, godly company for this tricke: if I be drunke, Ile
be drunke with those that haue the feare of God, and not
with drunken knaues.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: So got‑udge me, that is a vertuous minde.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You heare all these matters deni'd, Gentlemen;
you heare it.

sp.speaker: Mr.Page.
sp.p:
Nay daughter, carry the wine in, wee'll
drinke within.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Oh heauen: This is Mistresse Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Mr.Page.
sp.l: How now Mistris Ford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistris Ford, by my troth you are very wel met:
by your leaue good Mistris.

sp.speaker: Mr.Page.
sp.p:
Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome: come,
we haue a hot Venison pasty to dinner; Come gentle­
men, I hope we shall drinke downe all vnkindnesse.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had rather then forty shillings I had my booke
of Songs and Sonnets heere: How now Simple, where
haue you beene? I must wait on my selfe, must I? you
haue not the booke of Riddles about you, haue you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Booke of Riddles? why did you not lend it to
Alice Short‑cake vpon Alhallowmas last, a fortnight a­fore
Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Come Coz, come Coz, we stay for you: a word
with you Coz: marry this, Coz: there is as 'twere a ten­
der, a kinde of tender, made a farre‑off by Sir Hugh here:
doe you vnderstand me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I Sir, you shall finde me reasonable; if it be so,
I shall doe that that is reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Nay, but vnderstand me.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: So I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Giue eare to his motions; (Mr. Slender) I will
description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Nay, I will doe as my Cozen Shallow saies: I
pray you pardon me, he's a Iustice of Peace in his Coun­trie,
simple though I stand here.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
But that is not the question: the question is
concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I, there's the point Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Marry is it: the very point of it, to Mr. An Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Why if it be so; I will marry her vpon any rea­sonable
demands.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
But can you affection the 'o‑man, let vs command
to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for diuers
Philosophers hold, that the lips is parcell of the mouth:
therfore precisely, cā can you carry your good wil to yͤ maid?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Cosen Abraham Slender, can you loue her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I hope sir, I will do as it shall become one that
would doe reason.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Nay, got's Lords, and his Ladies, you must speake
possitable, if you can carry‑her your desires towards her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l:
That you must:
Will you, (vpon good dowry) marry her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will doe a greater thing then that, vpon your
request (Cosen) in any reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Nay conceiue me, conceiue mee, (sweet Coz):
What I doe is to pleasure you (Coz:) can you loue the
maid?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will marry her (Sir) at your request; but if
there bee no great loue in the beginning, yet Heauen
may decrease it vpon better acquaintance, when wee
are married, and haue more occasion to know one ano­
ther: I hope vpon familiarity will grow more content:
but if you say mary‑her, I will mary‑her, that I am freely
dissolued, and dissolutely.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
It is a fery discretion‑answere; saue the fall is in
the 'ord, dissolutely: the ort is (according to our mea­
ning) resolutely: his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I: I thinke my Cosen meant well.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: I, or else I would I might be hang'd (la.)

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Here comes faire Mistris Anne; would I were
yong for your sake, Mistris Anne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
The dinner is on the Table, my Father desires
your worships company.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I will wait on him, (faire Mistris Anne.)

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Od's plessed‑wil: I wil not be absēce absence at the grace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Wil't please your worship to come in, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: No, I thank you forsooth, hartely; I am very well.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: The dinner attends you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I am not a‑hungry, I thanke you, forsooth: goe,
Sirha, for all you are my man, goe wait vpon my Cosen
Shallow: a Iustice of peace sometime may be beholding
to his friend, for a Man; I keepe but three Men, and a
Boy yet, till my Mother be dead: but what though, yet
I liue like a poore Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
I may not goe in without your worship: they
will not sit till you come.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I'faith, ile eate nothing: I thanke you as much as
though I did.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I pray you Sir walke in.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I had rather walke here (I thanke you) I bruiz'd
my shin th' other day, with playing at Sword and Dag­
ger with a Master of Fence (three veneys for a dish of
stew'd Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the smell
of hot meate since. Why doe your dogs barke so? be
there Beares ith' Towne?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I thinke there are, Sir, I heard them talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I loue the sport well, but I shall as soone quarrell
at it, as any man in England: you are afraid if you see the
Beare loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I indeede Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
That's meate and drinke to me now: I haue seene
Saskerson loose, twenty times, and haue taken him by the
Chaine: but (I warrant you) the women haue so cride
and shrekt at it, that it past: But women indeede, cannot
abide 'em, they are very ill‑fauour'd rough things.

sp.speaker: Ma.Pa
sp.l: Come, gentle M. Slender, come; we stay for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Ile eate nothing, I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.Pa
sp.l:
By cocke and pie, you shall not choose, Sir:
come, come.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Nay, pray you lead the way.

sp.speaker: Ma.Pa.
sp.l: Come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Mistris Anne: your selfe shall goe first.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Not I Sir, pray you keepe on.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l:
Truely I will not goe first: truly‑la: I will not
doe you that wrong.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
Ile rather be vnmannerly, then troublesome: you
doe your selfe wrong indeede‑la.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Go your waies, and aske of Doctor Caius house,
which is the way; and there dwels one Mistris Quickly;
which is in the manner of his Nurse; or his dry‑Nurse; or
his Cooke; or his Laundry; his Washer, and his Ringer.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Nay, it is petter yet: giue her this letter; for it is
a 'oman that altogeathers acquaintāce acquaintance with Mistris Anne
Page; and the Letter is to desire, and require her to soli­
cite your Masters desires, to Mistris Anne Page: I pray
you be gon: I will make an end of my dinner; ther's Pip­
pins and Cheese to come.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
[Act 1, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Host, Bardolfe, Nym, Pistoll, Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mine Host of the Garter?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
What saies my Bully Rooke? speake schollerly,
and wisely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Truely mine Host; I must turne away some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Discard, (bully Hercules) casheere; let them wag;
trot, trot.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I sit at ten pounds a weeke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Thou'rt an Emperor (Cesar, Keiser and Pheazar)
I will entertaine Bardolfe: he shall draw; he shall tap; said
I well (bully Hector?)

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Doe so (good mine Host.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
I haue spoke; let him follow: let me see thee froth,
and liue: I am at a word: follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Bardolfe, follow him: a Tapster is a good trade:
an old Cloake, makes a new Ierkin: a wither'd Seruing­
man, a fresh Tapster: goe, adew.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: It is a life that I haue desir'd: I will thriue.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: O base hungarian wight: wilt yu the spigot wield.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: He was gotten in drink: is not the humor cōceited conceited ?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am glad I am so acquit of this Tinderbox: his
Thefts were too open: his filching was like an vnskilfull
Singer, he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The good humor is to steale at a minutes rest.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Conuay: the wise it call: Steale? foh: a fico for
the phrase.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well sirs, I am almost out at heeles.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Why then let Kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: There is no remedy: I must conicatch, I must shift.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Yong Rauens must haue foode.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Which of you know Ford of this Towne?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I ken the wight: he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: My honest Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No quips now Pistoll: (Indeede I am in the waste
two yards about: but I am now about no waste: I am a­
bout thrift) briefely: I doe meane to make loue to Fords
wife: I spie entertainment in her: shee discourses: shee
carues: she giues the leere of inuitation: I can construe
the action of her familier stile, & the hardest voice of her
behauior (to be english'd rightly) is, I am Sir Iohn Falstafs.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
He hath studied her will; and translated her will:
out of honesty, into English.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The Anchor is deepe: will that humor passe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, the report goes, she has all the rule of her
husbands Purse: he hath a legend of Angels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: As many diuels entertaine: and to her Boy say I.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The humor rises: it is good: humor me the angels.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I haue writ me here a letter to her: & here ano­
ther to Pages wife, who euen now gaue mee good eyes
too; examind my parts with most iudicious illiads: some­
times the beame of her view, guilded my foote: some­
times my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Then did the Sun on dung‑hill shine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: I thanke thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O she did so course o're my exteriors with such
a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did seeme
to scorch me vp like a burning‑glasse: here's another
letter to her: She beares the Purse too: She is a Region
in Guiana: all gold, and bountie: I will be Cheaters to
them both, and they shall be Exchequers to mee: they
shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to
them both: Goe, beare thou this Letter to Mistris Page;
and thou this to Mistris Ford: we will thriue (Lads) we
will thriue.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side weare Steele? then Lucifer take all.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l:
I will run no base humor: here take the humor‑
Letter; I will keepe the hauior of reputation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hold Sirha, beare you these Letters tightly,
Saile like my Pinnasse to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, auaunt, vanish like haile‑stones; goe,
Trudge; plod away ith' hoofe: seeke shelter, packe:
Falstaffe will learne the honor of the age,
French‑thrift, you Rogues, my selfe, and skirted Page.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Let Vultures gripe thy guts: for gourd, and
Fullam holds: & high and low beguiles the rich & poore,
Tester ile haue in pouch when thou shalt lacke,
Base Phrygian Turke.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: I haue opperations,
Which be humors of reuenge.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Wilt thou reuenge?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: By Welkin, and her Star.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: With wit, or Steele?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: With both the humors, I:
I will discusse the humour of this Loue to Ford.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: And I to Page shall eke vnfold
How Falstaffe (varlet vile)
His Doue will proue; his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
My humour shall not coole: I will incense Ford
to deale with poyson: I will possesse him with yallow­
nesse, for the reuolt of mine is dangerous: that is my
true humour.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Thou art the Mars of Malecontents: I second
thee: troope on.

div.head: Scœna Quarta.
[Act 1, Scene 4]
div.stage:
Enter Mistris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doctor,
Caius, Fenton.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee goe to the Case­
ment, and see if you can see my Master, Master Docter
Caius comming: if he doe (I'faith) and finde any body
in the house; here will be an old abusing of Gods pati­
ence, and the Kings English.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Ile goe watch.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Goe, and we'll haue a posset for't soone at night,
(in faith) at the latter end of a Sea‑cole‑fire: An honest,
willing, kinde fellow, as euer seruant shall come in house
withall: and I warrant you, no tel‑tale, nor no breede‑
bate: his worst fault is, that he is giuen to prayer; hee is
something peeuish that way: but no body but has his
fault: but let that passe. Peter Simple, you say your
name is?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I: for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And Master Slender's your Master?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Do's he not weare a great round Beard, like a
Glouers pairing‑knife?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
No forsooth: he hath but a little weeߛface;
with a little yellow Beard: a Caine colourd Beard.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A softly‑sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
I forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands, as
any is betweene this and his head: he hath fought with
a Warrener.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
How say you: oh, I should remember him: do's
he not hold vp his head (as it were?) and strut in his gate?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes indeede do's he.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Well, heauen send Anne Page, no worse fortune:
Tell Master Parson Euans, I will doe what I can for your
Master: Anne is a good girle, and I wish—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Out alas: here comes my Master.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
We shall all be shent: Run in here, good young
man: goe into this Closset: he will not stay long: what
Iohn Rugby? Iohn: what Iohn I say? goe Iohn, goe en­
quire for my Master, I doubt he be not well, that hee
comes not home: (and downe, downe, adowne'a. &c.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
Vat is you sing? I doe not like des‑toyes: pray
you goe and vetch me in my Closset, vnboyteene verd;
a Box, a greene‑a‑Box: do intend vat I speake? a greene‑
a‑Box.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I forsooth ile fetch it you:

I am glad hee went not in himselfe: if he had found the
yong man he would haue bin horne‑mad.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il fait for ehando, Ie man voi a le
Court la grand affaires.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is it this Sir?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Ouy mette le au mon pocket, de‑peech quickly:
Vere is dat knaue Rugby?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: You are Iohn Rugby, and you are Iacke Rugby:

Come, take‑a‑your Rapier, and come after my heele to
the Court.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: 'Tis ready Sir, here in the Porch.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
By my trot: I tarry too long: od's‑me: que ay ie
oublie: dere is some Simples in my Closset, dat I vill not
for the varld I shall leaue behinde.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ay‑me, he'll finde the yong man there, & be mad.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O Diable, Diable: vat is in my Closset?
Villanie, La‑roone: Rugby, my Rapier.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Good Master be content.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Wherefore shall I be content‑a?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The yong man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
What shall de honest man do in my Closset: dere
is no honest man dat shall come in my Closset.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
I beseech you be not so flegmaticke: heare the
truth of it. He came of an errand to mee, from Parson
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Vell.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I forsooth: to desire her to—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Peace‑a‑your tongue: speake‑a‑your Tale.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
To desire this honest Gentlewoman (your Maid)
to speake a good word to Mistris Anne Page, for my Ma­
ster in the way of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
This is all indeed‑la: but ile nere put my finger
in the fire, and neede not.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh send‑a you? Rugby, ballow mee some
paper: tarry you a littell‑a‑while.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
I am glad he is so quiet: if he had bin through­
ly moued, you should haue heard him so loud, and so me­
lancholly: but notwithstanding man, Ile doe yoe your
Master what good I can: and the very yea, & the no is, yͤ
French Doctor my Master, (I may call him my Master,
looke you, for I keepe his house; and I wash, ring, brew,
bake, scowre, dresse meat and drinke, make the beds, and
doe all my selfe.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
'Tis a great charge to come vnder one bodies
hand.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Are you a‑uis'd o'that? you shall finde it a great
charge: and to be vp early, and down late: but notwith­
standing, (to tell you in your eare, I wold haue no words
of it) my Master himselfe is in loue with Mistris Anne
Page: but notwithstanding that I know Ans mind, that's
neither heere nor there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
You, Iack'Nape: giue‑'a this Letter to Sir
Hugh, by gar it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat in de
Parke, and I will teach a scuruy Iack‑a‑nape Priest to
meddle, or make: — you may be gon: it is not good
you tarry here: by gar I will cut all his two stones: by
gar, he shall not haue a stone to throw at his dogge.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Alas: he speakes but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
It is no matter 'a ver dat: do not you tell‑a‑me
dat I shall haue Anne Page for my selfe? by gar, I vill
kill de Iack‑Priest: and I haue appointed mine Host of
de Iarteer to measure our weapon: by gar, I wil my selfe
haue Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Sir, the maid loues you, and all shall bee well:
We must giue folkes leaue to prate: what the good‑ier.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l:
Rugby, come to the Court with me: by gar, if
I haue not Anne Page, I shall turne your head out of my
dore: follow my heeles, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
You shall haue An‑fooles head of your owne:
No, I know Ans mind for that: neuer a woman in Wind­
sor knowes more of Ans minde then I doe, nor can doe
more then I doe with her, I thanke heauen.

sp.speaker: Fenton.
sp.l: Who's with in there, hoa?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l:
Who's there, I troa? Come neere the house I
pray you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: How now (good woman) how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l:
The better that it pleases your good Worship
to aske?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: What newes? how do's pretty Mistris Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
In truth Sir, and shee is pretty, and honest, and
gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by
the way, I praise heauen for it.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l:
Shall I doe any good thinkst thou? shall I not
loose my suit?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, all is in his hands aboue: but not­
withstanding (Master Fenton) Ile be sworne on a booke
shee loues you: haue not your Worship a wart aboue
your eye?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Yes marry haue I, what of that?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Wel, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is such
another Nan; (but (I detest) an honest maid as euer
broke bread: wee had an howres talke of that wart; I
shall neuer laugh but in that maids company: but (in­
deed) shee is giuen too much to Allicholy and musing:
but for you— well— goe too⸺

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p:
Well: I shall see her to day: hold, there's mo­
ney for thee: Let mee haue thy voice in my behalfe: if
thou seest her before me, commend me.⸺

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Will I? I faith that wee will: And I will tell
your Worship more of the Wart, the next time we haue
confidence, and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Well, fare‑well, I am in great haste now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Fare‑well to your Worship: truely an honest
Gentleman: but Anne loues hiim not: for I know Ans
minde as well as another do's: out vpon't: what haue I
forgot.

div.head: Actus Secundus. Scœna Prima.
[Act 2, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Master Page, Master
Ford, Pistoll, Nim, Quickly, Host, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Mist.Page.
sp.p:
What, haue scap'd Loue‑letters in the
holly‑day‑time of my beauty, and am I now a subiect
for them? let me see?

Aske me no reason why I loue you, for though Loue vse Rea­
son for his precisian, hee admits him not for his Counsailour:
you are not yong, no more am I: goe to then, there's simpathie:
you are merry, so am I: ha, ha, then there's more simpathie:
you loue sacke, and so do I: would you desire better simpathie?
Let it suffice thee (Mistris Page) at the least if the Loue of
Souldier can suffice, that I loue thee: I will not say pitty mee,
'tis not a Souldier‑like phrase; but I say, loue me:
sp.l: By me, thine owne true Knight, by day or night:
Or any kinde of light, with all his might,
For thee to fight. Iohn Falstaffe.
What a Herod of Iurie is this? O wicked, wicked world:
One that is well‑nye worne to peeces with age
To show himselfe a yong Gallant? What an vnwaied
Behauiour hath this Flemish drunkard pickt (with
The Deuills name) out of my conuersation, that he dares
In this manner assay me? why, hee hath not beene thrice
In my Company: what should I say to him? I was then
Frugall of my mirth: (heauen forgiue mee:) why Ile
Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting downe
of men: how shall I be reueng'd on him? for reueng'd I
will be? as sure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l:
Mistris Page, trust me, I was going to your
house.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l:
And trust me, I was comming to you: you
looke very ill.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l:
Nay Ile nere beleeee that; I haue to shew
to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l: 'Faith but you doe in my minde.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.p:
Well: I doe then: yet I say, I could shew
you to the contrary: O Mistris Page, giue mee some
counsaile.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.l:
O woman: if it were not for one trifling re­
spect,I could come to such honour.

sp.speaker: Mi.Page.
sp.p:
Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour:
what is it? dispence with trifles: what is it?

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.p:
If I would but goe to hell, for an eternall
moment, or so: I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mi.Page.
sp.p:
What thou liest? Sir Alice Ford? these
Knights will hacke, and so thou shouldst not alter the ar­
ticle of thy Gentry.

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.p:
Wee burne day‑light: heere, read, read:
perceiue how I might bee knighted, I shall thinke the
worse of fat men, as long as I haue an eye to make diffe­
rence of mens liking: and yet hee would not sweare: praise
The Merry Wiues of Windsor.
praise womens modesty: and gaue such orderly and wel‑
behaued reproofe to al vncomelinesse, that I would haue
sworne his disposition would haue gone to the truth of
his words: but they doe no more adhere and keep place
together, then the hundred Psalms to the tune of Green­sleeues: What tempest (I troa) threw this Whale, (with
so many Tuns of oyle in his belly) a'shoare at Windsor?
How shall I bee reuenged on him? I thinke the best way
were, to entertaine him with hope, till the wicked fire
of lust haue melted him in his owne greace: Did you e­
uer heare the like?

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.p:
Letter for letter; but that the name of
Page and Ford differs: to thy great comfort in this my­
stery of ill opinions, heere's the twyn‑brother of thy Let­
ter: but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine neuer
shall: I warrant he hath a thousand of these Letters, writ
with blancke‑space for different names (sure more): and
these are of the second edition: hee will print them out
of doubt: for he cares not what hee puts into the presse,
when he would put vs two: I had rather be a Giantesse,
and lye vnder Mount Pelion: Well; I will find you twen­
tie lasciuious Turtles ere one chaste man.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.p:
Why this is the very same: the very hand:
the very words: what doth he thinke of vs?

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.p:
Nay I know not: it makes me almost rea­
die to wrangle with mine owne honesty: Ile entertaine
my selfe like one that I am not acquainted withall: for
sure vnlesse hee know some straine in mee, that I know
not my selfe, hee would neuer haue boorded me in this
furie.

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.p:
Boording, call you it? Ile bee sure to keepe
him aboue decke.

sp.speaker: Mi.Page.
sp.p:
So will I: if hee come vnder my hatches,
Ile neuer to Sea againe: Let's bee reueng'd on him: let's
appoint him a meeting: giue him a show of comfort in
his Suit, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till hee
hath pawn'd his horses to mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, I wil consent to act any villany against
him, that may not sully the charinesse of our honesty: oh
that my husband saw this Letter: it would giue eternall
food to his iealousie.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.p:
Why look where he comes; and my good
man too: hee's as farre from iealousie, as I am from gi­
uing him cause, and that (I hope) is an vnmeasurable di­
stance.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.p:
Let's consult together against this greasie
Knight: Come hither.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well: I hope, it be not so.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Hope is a curtall‑dog in some affaires:
Sir Iohn affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Why sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
He wooes both high and low, both rich & poor,
both yong and old, one with another (Ford) he loues the
Gally‑mawfry (Ford) perpend.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Loue my wife?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: With liuer, burning hot: preuent:
Or goe thou like Sir Acteon he, with
Ring‑wood at thy heeles: O, odious is the name.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: What name Sir?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: The horne I say: Farewell:
Take heed, haue open eye, for theeues doe foot by night.
Take heed, ere sommer comes, or Cuckoo‑birds do sing.
Away sir Corporall Nim:
Beleeue it (Page) he speakes sence.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I will be patient: I will find out this.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p:
And this is true: I like not the humor of lying:
hee hath wronged mee in some humors: I should haue
borne the humour'd Letter to her: but I haue a sword:
and it shall bite vpon my necessitie: he loues your wife;
There's the short and the long: My name is Corporall
Nim: I speak, and I auouch; 'tis true: my name is Nim:
and Falstaffe loues your wife: adieu, I loue not the hu­
mour of bread and cheese: adieu.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
The humour of it (quoth'a?) heere's a fellow
frights English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I will seeke out Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I neuer heard such a drawling‑affecting rogue.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: If I doe finde it: well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
I will not beleeue such a Cataian, though the
Priest o' th' Towne commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: 'Twas a good sensible fellow: well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: How now Meg?

sp.speaker: Mist.Page.
sp.l: Whether goe you (George?) harke you.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l:
How now (sweet Frank) why art thou me­
lancholy?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home: goe.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l: Faith, thou hast some crochets in thy head,
Now: will you goe, Mistris Page?

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.p:
Haue with you: you'll come to dinner
George? Looke who comes yonder: shee shall bee our
Messenger to this paltrie Knight.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l: Trust me, I thought on her: shee'll fit it.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l:
I forsooth: and I pray how do's good Mistresse
Anne?

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l:
Go in with vs and see: we haue an houres
talke with you.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: How now Master Ford?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: You heard what this knaue told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Doe you thinke there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
Hang 'em slaues: I doe not thinke the Knight
would offer it: But these that accuse him in his intent
towards our wiues, are a yoake of his discarded men: ve‑
ry rogues, now they be out of seruice.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Marry were they.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I like it neuer the beter for that,
Do's he lye at the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I marry do's he: if hee should intend this voy­
age toward my wife, I would turne her loose to him;
and what hee gets more of her, then sharpe words, let it
lye on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I doe not misdoubt my wife: but I would bee
loath to turne them together: a man may be too confi­
dent: I would haue nothing lye on my head: I cannot
be thus satisfied.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Looke where my ranting‑Host of the Garter
comes: there is eyther liquor in his pate, or mony in his
purse, when hee lookes so merrily: How now mine
Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How now Bully‑Rooke: thou'rt a Gentleman
Caueleiro Iustice, I say.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I follow, (mine Host) I follow: Good‑euen,
and twenty (good Master Page.) Master Page, wil you go
with vs? we haue sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Tell him Caueleiro‑Iustice: tell him Bully‑
Rooke.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.l:
Sir, there is a fray to be fought, betweene Sir
Hugh the Welch Priest, and Caius the French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Good mine Host o'th' Garter: a word with you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: What saist thou, my Bully‑Rooke?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Will you goe with vs to behold it? My merry
Host hath had the measuring of their weapons; and (I
thinke) hath appointed them contrary places: for (be­
leeue mee) I heare the Parson is no Iester: harke, I will
tell you what our sport shall be.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Hast thou no suit against my Knight? my guest‑
Caualeire?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
None, I protest: but Ile giue you a pottle of
burn'd sacke, to giue me recourse to him, and tell him
my name is Broome: onely for a iest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
My hand, (Bully:) thou shalt haue egresse and
regresse, (said I well?) and thy name shall be Broome. It
is a merry Knight: will you goe An‑heires?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Haue with you mine Host.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
I haue heard the Frenchߛman hath good skill
in his Rapier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Tut sir: I could haue told you more: In these
times you stand on distance: your Passes, Stoccado's, and
I know not what: 'tis the heart (Master Page) 'tis heere,
'tis heere: I haue seene the time, with my long‑sword, I
would haue made you fowre tall fellowes skippe like
Rattes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Heere boyes, heere, heere: shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
Haue with you: I had rather heare them scold,
then fight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Though Page be a secure foole, and stands so
firmely on his wiues frailty; yet, I cannot put‑off my o­
pinion so easily: she was in his company at Pages house:
and what they made there, I know not. Well, I wil looke
further into't, and I haue a disguise, to sound Falstaffe; if
I finde her honest, I loose not my labor: if she be other­
wise, 'tis labour well bestowed.

div.head: Scœna Secunda
[Act 2, Scene 2]
div.stage:
Enter Falstaffe, Pistoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe,
Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
Why then the world's mine Oyster, which I,
with sword will open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not a penny: I haue beene content (Sir,) you
should lay my countenance to pawne: I haue grated vp­
on my good friends for three Repreeues for you, and
your Coach‑fellow Nim; or else you had look'd through
the grate, like a Geminy of Baboones: I am damn'd in
hell, for swearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were
good Souldiers, and tall‑fellowes. And when Mistresse
Briget lost the handle of her Fan, I took't vpon mine ho­
nour thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l:
Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteene
pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Reason, you roague, reason: thinkst thou Ile en­
danger my soule, gratis? at a word, hang no more about
mee, I am no gibbet for you: goe, a short knife, and a
throng, to your Mannor of Pickt‑hatch: goe, you'll not
beare a Letter for mee you roague? you stand vpon your
honor: why, (thou vnconfinable basenesse) it is as much
as I can doe to keepe the termes of my honor precise:
I, I, I my selfe sometimes, leauing the feare of heauen on
the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my necessity, am
faine to shufflle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you
Rogue, will en‑sconce your raggs; your Cat‑a‑Moun­
taine‑lookes, your red‑lattice phrases, and your bold‑
beating‑oathes, vnder the shelter of your honor? you
will not doe it? you?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I doe relent: what would thou more of man?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Sir, here's a woman would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Giue your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Good‑morrow, good‑wife.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Not so, and't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Good maid then.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Ile be sworne,
As my mother was the first houre I was borne.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I doe beleeue the swearer; what with me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l:
Shall I vouch‑safe your worship a word, or
two?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Two thousand (faire woman) and ile vouchsafe
thee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
There is one Mistresse Ford, (Sir) I pray come a
little neerer this waies: I my selfe dwell with M. Doctor
Caius:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well, on; Mistresse Ford, you say.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Your worship saies very true: I pray your wor­
ship come a little neerer this waies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I warrant thee, no‑bodie heares: mine owne
people, mine owne people

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Are they so? heauen‑blesse them, and make
them his Seruants.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well; Mistresse Ford, what of her?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Why, Sir; shee's a good‑creature; Lord, Lord,
your Worship's a wanton: well: heauen forgiue you,
and all of vs, I pray—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Mistresse Ford: come, Mistresse Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry this is the short, and the long of it: you
haue brought her into such a Canaries, as 'tis wonder­
full: the best Courtier of them all (when the Court lay
at Windsor) could neuer haue brought her to such a Ca­
narie: yet there has beene Knights, and Lords, and Gen­
tlemen, with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after
Coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, smelling so sweet­
ly; all Muske, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silke
and golde, and in such alligant termes, and in such wine
and suger of the best, and the fairest, that would haue
wonne any womans heart: and I warrant you, they could
neuer get an eyeߛwinke of her: I had my selfe twentie
Angels giuen me this morning, but I defie all Angels (in
any such sort, as they say) but in the way of honesty: and
I warrant you, they could neuer get her so much as sippe
on a cup with the prowdest of them all, and yet there has
beene Earles: nay, (which is more) Pentioners, but I
warrant you all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
But what saies shee to mee? be briefe my good
shee‑Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry, she hath receiu'd your Letter: for the
which she thankes you a thousand times; and she giues
you to notifie, that her husband will be absence from his
house, betweene ten and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ten, and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
I, forsooth: and then you may come and see the
picture (she sayes) that you wot of: Master Ford her hus­
band will be from home: alas, the sweet woman leades
an ill life with him: hee's a very iealousie‑man; she leads
a very frampold life with him, (good hart.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ten, and eleuen.
Woman, commend me to her, I will not faile her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Why, you say well: But I haue another messen­
ger to your worship: Mistresse Page hath her heartie
commendations to you to: and let mee tell you in your
eare, shee's as fartuous a ciuill modest wife, and one (I
tell you) that will not misse you morning nor euening
prayer, as any is in Windsor, who ere bee the other: and
shee bade me tell your worship, that her husband is sel­
dome from home, but she hopes there will come a time.
I neuer knew a woman so doate vpon a man; surely I
thinke you haue charmes, la: yes in truth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not I, I assure thee; setting the attraction of my
good parts aside, I haue no other charmes.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Blessing on your heart for't.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But I pray thee tell me this: has Fords wife, and
Pages wife acquainted each other, how they loue me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
That were a iest indeed: they haue not so little
grace I hope, that were a tricke indeed: But Mistris Page
would desire you to send her your little Page of al loues:
her husband has a maruellous
infectiō infection to the little Page:
and truely Master Page is an honest man: neuer a wife in
Windsor leades a better life then she do's: doe what shee
will, say what she will, take all, pay all, goe to bed when
she list, rise when she list, all is as she will: and truly she
deserues it; for if there be a kinde woman in Windsor, she
is one: you must send her your Page, no remedie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Nay, but doe so then, and looke you, hee may
come and goe betweene you both: and in any case haue
a nay‑word, that you may know one anothers minde,
and the Boy neuer neede to vnderstand any thing; for'
tis not good that children should know any wickednes:
olde folkes you know, haue discretion, as they say, and
know the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Farethee‑well, commend mee to them both:
there's my purse, I am yet thy debter: Boy, goe along
with this woman, this newes distracts me.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: This Puncke is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap on more sailes, pursue: vp with your fights:
Giue fire: she is my prize, or Ocean whelme them all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Saist thou so (old Iacke) go thy waies: Ile make
more of thy olde body then I haue done: will they yet
looke after thee? wilt thou after the expence of so much
money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thanke thee: let
them say 'tis grossely done, so it bee fairely done, no
matter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, there's one Master Broome below would
faine speake with you, and be acquainted with you; and
hath sent your worship a mornings draught of Sacke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Broome is his name?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Call him in: such Broomes are welcome to mee,
that ore'flowes such liquor: ah ha, Mistresse Ford and Mi­
stresse Page, haue I encompass'd you? goe to, via.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: 'Blesse you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And you sir: would you speake with me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I make bold, to presse, with so little prepara­
tion vpon you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
You'r welcome, what's your will? giue vs leaue
Drawer.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l:
Sir, I am a Gentleman that haue spent much,
my name is Broome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Good Master Broome, I desire more acquaintance
of you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Good Sir Iohn, I sue for yours: not to charge
you, for I must let you vnderstand, I thinke my selfe in
better plight for a Lender, then you are: the which hath
something emboldned me to this vnseason'd intrusion:
for they say, if money goe before, all waies doe lye
open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Money is a good Souldier (Sir) and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Troth, and I haue a bag of money heere trou­
bles me:
                                    if you will helpe to beare it (Sir Iohn)
                                    take all, 
or halfe, for easing me of the carriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Sir, I know not how I may deserue to bee your
Porter.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l:
I will tell you sir, if you will giue mee the hea­
ring.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Speake (good Master Broome) I shall be glad to
be your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Sir, I heare you are a Scholler: (I will be briefe
with you) and you haue been a man long knowne to me,
though I had neuer so good means as desire, to make my
selfe acquainted with you. I shall discouer a thing to
you, wherein I must very much lay open mine owne im­
perfection: but (good Sir Iohn) as you haue one eye vp­
on my follies, as you heare them vnfolded, turne another
into the Register of your owne, that I may passe with a
reproofe the easier, sith you your selfe know how easie it
is to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Very well Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l:
There is a Gentlewoman in this Towne, her
husbands name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I haue long lou'd her, and I protest to you, be­
stowed much on her: followed her with a doating ob­
seruance: Ingross'd opportunities to meete her: fee'd e­
uery slight occasion that could but nigardly giue mee
sight of her: not only bought many presents to giue her,
but haue giuen largely to many, to know what shee
would haue giuen: briefly, I haue pursu'd her, as Loue
hath pursued mee, which hath beene on the wing of all
occasions: but whatsoeuer I haue merited, either in my
minde, or in my meanes, meede I am sure I haue receiued
none, vnlesse Experience be a Iewell, that I haue purcha­
sed at an infinite rate, and that hath taught mee to say
this,
sp.l: “Loue like a shadow flies, when substance Loue pursues,
“Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Haue you receiu'd no promise of satisfaction at
her hands?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Haue you importun'd her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Of what qualitie was your loue then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Like a fair house, built on another mans ground,
so that I haue lost my edifice, by mistaking the place,
where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: To what purpose haue you vnfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
When I haue told you that, I haue told you all:
Some say, that though she appeare honest to mee, yet in
other places shee enlargeth her mirth so farre, that there
is shrewd construction made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here
is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of ex­
cellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admit­
tance, authenticke in your place and person, generally
allow'd for your many war⸗like, court‑like, and learned
preparations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Beleeue it, for you know it: there is money,
spend it, spend it, spend more; spend all I haue, onely giue
The Merry Wiues of Windsor.
giue me so much of your time in enchange of it, as to lay
an amiable siege to the honesty of this Fords wife: vse
your Art of wooing; win her to consent to you: if any
man may, you may as soone as any.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affection that I should win what you would enioy? Me­
thinkes you prescribe to your selfe very preposterously.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
O, vnderstand my drift: she dwells so securely
on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my soule
dares not present it selfe: shee is too bright to be look'd
against. Now, could I come to her with any detection
in my hand; my desires had instance and argument to
commend themselues, I could driue her then from the
ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage‑vow,
and a thousand other her defences, which now are too‑
too strongly embattaild against me: what say you too't,
Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Broome, I will first make bold with your
money: next, giue mee your hand: and last, as I am a
gentleman, you shall, if you will, enioy Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: O good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you shall want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Want no Mistresse Ford (Master Broome) you shall
want none: I shall be with her (I may tell you) by her
owne appointment, euen as you came in to me, her assi­
stant, or goe‑betweene, parted from me: I say I shall be
with her betweene ten and eleuen: for at that time the
iealious‑rascally‑knaue her husband will be forth: come
you to me at night, you shall know how I speed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l:
I am blest in your acquaintance: do you know
Ford Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him (poore Cuckoldly knaue) I know
him not: yet I wrong him to call him poore: They say
the iealous wittolly‑knaue hath masses of money, for
the which his wife seemes to me well‑fauourd: I will vse
her as the key of the Cuckoldly‑rogues Coffer, & ther's
my haruest‑home.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might a­
uoid him, if you saw him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanicall‑salt‑butter rogue; I wil
stare him out of his wits: I will awe‑him with my cud­
gell: it shall hang like a Meteor ore the Cuckolds horns:
Master Broome, thou shalt know, I will predominate o­
uer the pezant, and thou shalt lye with his wife. Come
to me soone at night: Ford's a knaue, and I will aggra­
uate his stile: thou (Master Broome) shalt know him for
knaue, and Cuckold. Come to me soone at night.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
What a damn'd EpicurianߛRascall is this? my
heart is ready to cracke with impatience: who saies this is
improuident iealousie? my wife hath sent to him, the
howre is fixt, the match is made: would any man haue
thought this? see the hell of hauing a false woman: my
bed shall be abus'd, my Coffers ransack'd, my reputati­
on gnawne at, and I shall not onely receiue this villainous
wrong, but stand vnder the adoption of abhominable
termes, and by him that does mee this wrong: Termes,
names: Amaimon sounds well: Lucifer, well: Barbason,
well: yet they are Diuels additions, the names of fiends:
But Cuckold, Wittoll, Cuckold? the Diuell himselfe
hath not such a name. Page is an Asse, a secure Asse; hee
will trust his wife, hee will not be iealous: I will rather
trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welsh­
man with my Cheese, an Irish‑man with my Aqua‑vitæ‑bottle,
or a Theefe to walke my ambling gelding, then
my wife with her selfe. Then she plots, then shee rumi­
nates, then shee deuises: and what they thinke in their
hearts they may effect; they will breake their hearts but
they will effect. Heauen bee prais'd for my iealousie:
eleuen o'clocke the howre, I will preuent this, detect
my wife, bee reueng'd on Falstaffe, and laugh at Page. I
will about it, better three houres too soone, then a my­
nute too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
[Act 2, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Iacke Rugby.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Vat is the clocke, Iack.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l:
'Tis past the howre (Sir) that Sir Hugh promis'd
to meet.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By gar, he has saue his soule, dat he is no‑come:
hee has pray his Pible well, dat he is no‑come: by gar
(Iack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
Hee is wise Sir: hee knew your worship would
kill him if he came.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By gar, de herring is no dead, so as I vill kill
him: take your Rapier, (Iacke) I vill tell you how I vill
kill him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Alas sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Villaine, take your Rapier.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Forbeare: heer's company.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Blesse thee, bullyߛDoctor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: 'Saue you Mr. Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Now good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: 'Giue you goodߛmorrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: Vat be all you one, two, tree, fowre, come for?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
To see thee fight, to see thee foigne, to see thee
trauerse, to see thee heere, to see thee there, to see thee
passe thy puncto, thy stock, thy reuerse, thy distance, thy
montant: Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Fran­
cisco? ha Bully? what saies my Esculapius? my Galien? my
heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully‑Stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By gar, he is de Coward‑Iack‑Priest of de vorld:
he is not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Thou art a Castalion‑king‑Vrinall: Hector of
Greece (my Boy)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I pray you beare witnesse, that me haue stay,
sixe or seuen, two tree howres for him, and hee is no‑
come.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He is the wiser man (M.Docto) rhe (M. Doctor) he is a curer of
soules, and you a curer of bodies: if you should fight, you
goe against the haire of your professions: is it not true,
Master Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
Master Shallow; you haue your selfe beene a
great fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Body‑kins M. Page, though I now be old, and
of the peace; if I see a sword out, my finger itches to
make one: though wee are Iustices, and Doctors, and
Church‑men (M. Page) wee haue some salt of our youth
in vs, we are the sons of women (M. Page.)

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
It wil be found so, (M. Page:) M. Doctor Caius,
I am come to fetch you home: I am sworn of the peace:
you haue show'd your selfe a wise Physician, and Sir
Hugh hath showne himselfe a wise and patient Church­
man: you must goe with me, M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Pardon, Guest‑Iustice; a Mounseur Mocke­
water

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Mock‑vater? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Mock‑water, in our English tongue, is Valour
(Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
By gar, then I haue as much Mock‑vater as de
Englishman: scuruy‑Iack‑dog‑Priest: by gar, mee vill
cut his eares.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He will Clapper‑claw thee tightly (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Clapper‑de‑claw? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
By‐gar, me doe looke hee shall clapper‐de‐claw
me, for by‐gar, me vill haue it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And I will prouoke him to't, or let him wag.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Me tanck you for dat.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
And moreouer, (Bully) but first, Mr. Ghuest,
and M. Page, & eeke Caualeiro Slender, goe you through
the Towne to Frogmore.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
He is there, see what humor he is in: and I will
bring the Doctor about by the Fields: will it doe well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: We will doe it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Adieu, good M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
By‑gar, me vill kill de Priest, for he speake for a
Iack‑an‑Ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Let him die: sheath thy impatience: throw cold
water on thy Choller: goe about the fields with mee
through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Mistris Anne
Page is, at a Farm‑house a Feasting: and thou shalt wooe
her: Cride‑game, said I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By‑gar, mee dancke you vor dat: by gar I loue
you: and I shall procure 'a you de good Guest: de Earle,
de Knight, de Lords, de Gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
For the which, I will be thy aduersary toward
Anne Page: said I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: By‑gar, 'tis good: vell said.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let vs wag then.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Come at my heeles, Iack Rugby.

div.head: Actus Tertius. Scœna Prima.
[Act 3, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Caius,
Rugby.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
I pray you now, good Master Slenders seruing­
man, and friend Simple by your name; which way haue
you look'd for Master Caius, that calls himselfe Doctor
of Phisicke.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l:
Marry Sir, the pittie‑ward, the Parke‑ward:
euery way: olde Windsor way, and euery way but the
Towne‑way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
I most‑fehemently desire you, you will also
looke that way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
'Plesse my soule: how full of Chollors I am, and
trempling of minde: I shall be glad if he haue deceiued
me: how melancholies I am? I will knog his Vrinalls a­
bout his knaues costard, when I haue good opportunities
for the orke: 'Plesse my soule: To shallow Riuers to whose
falls: melodious Birds sings Madrigalls: There will we make
our Peds of Roses: and a thousand fragrant posies. To shal­
low: 'Mercie on mee, I haue a great dispositions to cry.
Melodious birds sing Madrigalls: —When as I sat in Pa­
bilon: and a thousand vagram Posies. To shallow, &c.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yonder he is comming, this way, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Hee's welcome: To shallow Riuers, to whose fals:
Heauen prosper the right: what weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l:
No weapons, Sir: there comes my Master, Mr.
Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, ouer
the stile, this way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l:
Pray you giue mee my gowne, or else keepe it
in your armes.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l:
How now Master Parson? good morrow good
Sir Hugh: keepe a Gamester from the dice, and a good
Studient from his booke, and it is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: Ah sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: 'Saue you, good Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: 'Plesse you from his mercy‑sake, all of you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Doe you study them both, Mr. Parson?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
And youthfull still, in your doublet and hose,
this raw‑rumaticke day?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: There is reasons, and causes for it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
We are come to you, to doe a good office, Mr.
Parson.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Fery‑well: what is it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yonder is a most reuerend Gentleman; who
(be‑like) hauing receiued wrong by some person, is at
most odds with his owne grauity and patience, that euer
you saw.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I haue liued foure‑score yeeres, and vpward: I
neuer heard a man of his place, grauity, and learning, so
wide of his owne respect.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I thinke you know him: Mr. Doctor Caius the
renowned French Physician.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Got's‑will, and his passion of my heart: I had
as lief you would tell me of a messe of porredge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l:
He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and
Galen, and hee is a knaue besides: a cowardly knaue, as
you would desires to be acquainted withall.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l:
I warrant you, hee's the man should fight with
him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l:
It appeares so by his weapons: keepe them a­
sunder: here comes Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Nay good Mr. Parson, keepe in your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: So doe you, good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Disarme them, and let them question: let them
keepe their limbs whole, and hack our English.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I pray you let‑a‑mee speake a word with your
eare; vherefore vill you not meet‑a me?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Pray you vse your patience in good time.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
By‑gar, you are de Coward: de Iack dog: Iohn
Ape.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Pray you let vs not be laughing‑stocks to other
mens humors: I desire you in friendship, and I will one
way or other make you amends: I will knog your Vrinal
about your knaues Cogs‑combe.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
Diable: Iack Rugby: mine Host de Iarteer: haue I
not stay for him, to kill him? haue I not at de place I did
appoint?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l:
As I am a Christians‑soule, now looke you:
this is the place appointed, Ile bee iudgement by mine
Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaule, French & Welch,
Soule‑Curer, and Body‑Curer.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: I, dat is very good, excellant.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Peace, I say: heare mine Host of the Garter,
Am I politicke? Am I subtle? Am I a Machiuell?
sp.p:
Shall I loose my Doctor? No, hee giues me the Potions
and the Motions. Shall I loose my Parson? my Priest?
my Sir Hugh? No, he giues me the Prouerbes, and the
No‑verbes. Giue me thy hand (Celestiall) so: Boyes of
Art, I haue deceiu'd you both: I haue directed you to
wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your skinnes are
whole, and let burn'd Sacke be the issue: Come, lay their
swords to pawne: Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, fol­
low, follow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l:
Trust me, a mad Host: follow Gentlemen, fol­
low.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
Ha' do I perceiue dat? Haue you make‑a‑de‑sot
of vs, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
This is well, he has made vs his vlowting‑stog:
I desire you that we may be friends: and let vs knog our
praines together to be reuenge on this same scall‑scur­
uy‑cogging‑companion the Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By gar, with all my heart: he promise to bring
me where is Anne Page: by gar he deceiue me too.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Well, I will smite his noddles: pray you follow.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
[Act 3, Scene 2]
div.stage:
Mist. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host,
Euans, Caius.

sp.speaker: Mist.Page.
sp.p:
Nay keepe your way (little Gallant) you
were wont to be a follower, but now you are a Leader:
whether had your rather lead mine eyes, or eye your ma­
sters heeles?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I had rather (forsooth) go before you like a man,
then follow him like a dwarfe.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.l:
O you are a flattering boy, now I see you'l be a
(Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Well met mistris Page, whether go you.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.l: Truly Sir, to see your wife, is she at home?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l:
I, and as idle she may hang together for want
of company: I think if your husbands were dead, you
two would marry.

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: Be sure of that, two other husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Where had your this pretty weather‑cocke?

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l:
I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my
husband had him of, what do you cal your Knights name
(sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.l:
He, he I can neuer hit on's name: there is such a
league between my goodman, and he: is your Wife at
(home indeed?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: M.Pa.
sp.l: By your leaue sir, I am sicke till I see her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Has Page any braines? Hath he any eies? Hath he
any thinking? Sure they sleepe, he hath no vse of them:
why this boy will carrie a letter twentie mile as easie, as
a Canon will shoot point‑blanke twelue score: hee pee­
ces out his wiues inclination: he giues her folly motion
and aduantage: and now she's going to my wife, Fal­
staffes boy with her: A man may heare this showre sing
in the winde; and Falstaffes boy with her: good plots,
they are laide, and our reuolted wiues share damnation
together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife,
plucke the borrowed vaile of modestie from the so‑see­
ming Mist. Page, divulge Page himselfe for a secure and
wilfull Acteon, and to these violent proceedings all my
neighbors shall cry aime. The clocke giues my Qu,
and my assurance bids me search, there I shall finde Fal­
staffe: I shall be rather praisd for this, then mock'd, for
it is as possitiue, as the earth is firme, that Falstaffe is
there: I will go.

sp.speaker: Shal. Page &c.
sp.p: Well met Mr Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Trust me a good knotte; I haue good cheere at
home, and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I must excuse my selfe Mr. Ford.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: And so must I Sir,
We haue appointed to dine with Mistris Anne,
And I would not breake with her for more mony
Then Ile speake of.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
We haue linger'd about a match betweene An
Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day wee shall haue
our answer.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: I hope I haue your good will Father Page.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: You haue Mr Slender, I stand wholly for you,
But my wife (Mr Doctor) is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l:
I be‑gar, and de Maid is loue‑a‑me: my nursh‑
a‑Quickly
tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What say you to yong Mr Fenton? He capers,
he dances, he has eies of youth: he writes verses, hee
speakes holliday, he smels April and May, he wil carry't,
he will carry't, 'tis in his buttons, he will carry't.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Not by my consent I promise you. The Gentle­
man is of no hauing, hee kept companie with the wilde
Prince, and Pointz: he is of too high a Region, he knows
too much: no, hee shall not knit a knot in his fortunes,
with the finger of my substance: if he take her, let him
take her simply: the wealth I haue waits on my consent,
and my consent goes not that way.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I beseech you heartily, some of you goe home
with me to dinner: besides your cheere you shall haue
sport, I will shew you a monster: Mr Doctor, you shal
go, so shall you Mr Page, and you Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well, fare you well:
We shall haue the freer woing at Mr Pages.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.l: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l:
Farewell my hearts, I will to my honest Knight
Falstaffe, and drinke Canarie with him.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I thinke I shall drinke in Pipe‑wine first with
him, Ile make him dance. Will you go Gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Haue with you, to see this Monster.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
[Act 3, Scene 3]
div.stage:
Enter M.Ford, M.Page, Seruants, Robin, Falstaffe,
Ford, Page, Caius, Euans.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l: What Iohn, what Robert.

sp.speaker: M.Page.
sp.l: Quickly, quickly: Is the Buck‑basket—

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l: I warrant. What Robin I say.

sp.speaker: Mis.Page.
sp.l: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l: Heere, set it downe.

sp.speaker: M.Pag.
sp.l: Giue your men the charge, we must be briefe.

sp.speaker: M.Ford.
sp.p:
Marrie, as I told you before (Iohn & Robert)
be ready here hard‑by in the Brew‑house, & when I so­
dainly call you, come forth, and (without any pause, or
staggering) take this basket on your shoulders: yt done,
trudge with it in all hast, and carry it among the Whit­
sters in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddie
ditch, close by the Thames side.

sp.speaker: M.Page.
sp.l: You will do it?

sp.speaker: M.Ford.
sp.l:
I ha told them ouer and ouer, they lacke no
(direction.
Be gone, and come when you are call'd.

sp.speaker: M.Page.
sp.l: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l:
How now my Eyas‑Musket, what newes
(with you?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My M. Sir Iohn is come in at your backe doore
(Mist. Ford, and requests your company.

sp.speaker: M.Page.
sp.l: You litle Iack‑a‑lent, haue you bin true to vs

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l:
I, Ile be sworne: my Master knowes not of your
being heere: and hath threatned to put me into euerla­
sting liberty, if I tell you of it: for he sweares he'll turne
me away.

sp.speaker: Mist.Pag.
sp.p:
Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine
shall be a Tailor to thee, and shal make thee a new dou­
blet and hose. Ile go hide me.

sp.speaker: Mi.Ford.
sp.l:
Do so: go tell thy Master, I am alone: Mi­
stris Page, remember you your Qu.

sp.speaker: Mist.Pag.
sp.l: I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hisse me.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.p:
Go‑too then: we'l vse this vnwholsome
humidity, this grosse‑watry Pumpion; we'll teach him
to know Turtles from Iayes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Haue I caught thee, my heauenly Iewell? Why
now let me die, for I haue liu'd long enough: This is the
period of my ambition: O this blessed houre.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l: O sweet Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Mistris Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Mist.
Ford) now shall I sin in my wish; I would thy Husband
were dead, Ile speake it before the best Lord, I would
make thee my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l:
I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I should bee a
pittifull Lady.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Let the Court of France shew me such another:
I see how thine eye would emulate the Diamond: Thou
hast the right arched‑beauty of the brow, that becomes
the Ship‑tyre, the Tyre‑valiant, or any Tire of Venetian
admittance.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l: A plaine Kerchiefe, Sir Iohn:
My browes become nothing else, nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou art a tyrant to say so: thou wouldst make
an absolute Courtier, and the firme fixture of thy foote,
would giue an excellent motion to thy gate, in a semi‑
circled Farthingale. I see what thou wert if Fortune thy
foe, were not Nature thy friend: Come, thou canst not
hide it.

sp.speaker: Mist.Ford.
sp.l: Beleeue me, ther's no such thing in me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What made me loue thee? Let that perswade
thee. Ther's something extraordinary in thee: Come, I
cannot cog, and say thou art this and that, like a‑manie
of these lisping‑hauthorne buds, that come like women
in mens apparrell, and smell like Bucklers‑berry in sim­
ple time: I cannot, but I loue thee, none but thee; and
thou deseru'st it.

sp.speaker: M.Ford.
sp.l: Do not betray me sir, I fear you loue M Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l:
Thou mightst as well say, I loue to walke by the
Counter‑gate, which is as hatefull to me, as the reeke of
a Lime‑kill.

sp.speaker: Mis.Ford.
sp.l: Well, heauen knowes how I loue you,
